choices.A: The _sips DNS record must target expE-pub.cll-collab.internal and the _cisco-uds DNS record must be removed.
choices.D: The HTTP allow list is not allowing communication with the Instant Message and Presence server.
choices.B: The collab-edge DNS record must be added to the DNS server and the _cisco-uds DNS record must be removed.
choices.C: A Cisco CSF device must be configured in UC for the user and the _cisco-uds DNS record must be removed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B seems correct, for MRA the cisco-uds record should not be resolvable via public DNS, and the collab-edge record is required
The signaling does not make it back to the endpoint because the firewall cannot inspect encrypted traffic.

Selected Answer: A
Don't like this question. However, the key to the question is that we're talking about signaling that is encrypted. That means TLS over TCP/IP. Since the station is initiating the connection to the outside via TCP/IP (with TLS on top), the signaling traffic will go through, and return traffic come back via the dynamic NAT from the firewall. Has nothing to do with the traffic being "always trusted" though. The media is a different story. Media exchange would fail as the device would not be reachable from the outside without additional collaboration ifnrastructure unless you are using some form of static NAT. So, the best answer here is A.

comments.content: A NAT ALG is similar to a firewall ALG, but a NAT ALG actually changes (maps) the addresses and ports in the signaling messages. The NAT ALG cannot inspect the contents of encrypted signaling messages. Answer C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If the signaling flows do not go through the firewall so that the firewall can inspect the signaling traffic, the RTP streams could be blocked because the firewall will not know which ports need to be opened to allow the RTP streams for a conversation.

 https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab12/collab12/security.html

Selected Answer: C
Answer C, because firewall cannot inspect the encrypted traffic and is not able to rewrite ip addresses
The signaling does not make it back.

choices.C: The signaling does not make it back to the endpoint because the firewall cannot inspect encrypted traffic.
choices.B: Encrypted IP traffic for collaboration devices always is trusted by the firewall.
choices.A: The signaling makes it back to the endpoint because the firewall is an application layer gateway and provides address translation.
choices.D: The signaling makes it back to the endpoint because the endpoint sent the private address to the external endpoint.

questions.question_text: What happens to the encrypted signaling traffic of a collaboration device if you place it inside a firewall with private IP addresses and try to make a call over IP without any collaboration infrastructure?

discussion.content: This should be B not D.

Selected Answer: B
The first time you log in to the Expressway web user interface you'll automatically see the Service Setup Wizard. (For subsequent log ins you'll see the Status > Overview page, and from that page you can click Run service setup at anytime.)

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/expressway/config_guide/X14-0/basic_config/exwy_b_cisco-expressway-e-and-expressway-c-basic-configuration-deployment-guide-x14-0/exwy_m_run-the-service-setup-wizard.html#concept_8D0B90ED41749AA37FFFA48B2EA8343B

choices.B: From the GUI of the Expressway server, go to Status> Overview> Run service setup.
choices.A: Factory reset the Expressway server to pass from Smart Licensing to PAK-based licensing.
choices.D: From the GUI of the Expressway server, go to Maintenance> Option keys> First Setup Wizard.
choices.C: Factory reset the Expressway server to pass from Expressway-C to Expressway-E.

What is the last step for domain management in Cisco Webex Control Hub if an engineer adds users already signed in with the company domain?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

1) add domain 2) verify domain 3) Claim the domain

questions.question_text: Which user management method uses the Webex Directory Connector to add and synchronize users to the Control Hub organization?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

The user management method that uses the Webex Directory Connector to add and synchronize users to the Control Hub organization is:

A. Synchronize from Active Directory.

The Webex Directory Connector allows organizations to synchronize user information, including user accounts and attributes, from their on-premises Active Directory environment to the Webex Control Hub organization. This synchronization ensures that user accounts are consistent across both environments and facilitates centralized management of user identities.
